title: After a third lackluster loss, Redskins’ defense has few answers for how to fix things
text:
Washington Redskins cornerback Josh Norman (24) looks on after a Redskins penalty, alongside linebacker Jon Bostic (53) and safety Montae Nicholson (35). (Ricky Carioti/The Washington Post)

Perhaps the most humbling moment of the Washington Redskins’ 31-15 loss on Monday night came near the end of the second quarter, when cornerback Josh Norman was beat on an out-and-up route to the end zone. Chicago Bears wide receiver Taylor Gabriel came down with an acrobatic 36-yard catch near the pylon, but officials had ruled he stepped out. Norman hovered above his opponent, waving his arms in a taunting manner, as if he was certain Gabriel had not scored.

Except after officials reviewed the play, they determined that Gabriel had indeed got both feet inbounds for a touchdown. The Bears led 28-0 at that point, demoralizing Norman and a defense that gave up at least 30 points for a third straight loss to open the season.

The lackluster performance was compounded by the fact that it came against Bears quarterback Mitchell Trubisky, who had struggled with his accuracy through his first two games this season and had not yet thrown a touchdown pass. Trubisky had three in the first half alone — all to the speedy Gabriel, defended by Norman, at least in part — and finished 25-for-31 for 231 yards on a night when he rarely faced pressure. Washington created no turnovers, as their offense committed five.

A week after Coach Jay Gruden called defensive coordinator Greg Manusky’s unit “vanilla” in a loss to Dallas, Manusky’s defense again looked bland and incapable of big plays Monday.

“We just have to keep pushing, man. We just have to keep pushing. This thing is a sprint, not a marathon,” Norman said. “It’s the first quarter of the season. Right now we’re 0-3. … All we can do is look forward to is the Giants, go in there and get a win.”

[Svrluga: At 0-3, it’s time to ask: What is this Redskins season even about?]

That game at New York next week, against a Giants team reinvigorated by rookie quarterback Daniel Jones, will be considered a must-win for these Redskins, who were searching for answers to the same bitter questions on Monday night. Was communication and missed assignments to blame for the defense’s poor first half start? Was it the scheme that couldn’t stop a struggling Trubisky? Is it the fault of Manusky, the third-year coordinator who has received plenty of criticism recently? And what could this unit possibly do this week to turn everything around and save the season?

Most members of the defense didn’t have solid answers.

“You look at the film, we’re just not getting pass rush. Letting guys get wide open. The defense isn’t communicating. We’re just not doing the little things right,” said defensive lineman Jonathan Allen. “There’s not a secret recipe to play good defense, to play hard, play physical and communicate. We have to find out where the lack of communication, physicality and effort is, starting with myself.”

“We stand together. Just have to build something,” Redskins safety Landon Collins said. “Somebody’s gotta do something.”

There was little pressure by Washington on Trubisky, who had entered Monday night having struggled with his accuracy. He broke his no-touchdown streak on a second-and-goal play from the Washington three-yard line, when Chicago ran its grouping of receivers one direction into the end zone and Gabriel slipped through the traffic underneath to the backside. Linebacker Ryan Anderson froze and watched Gabriel run by him. He was all alone. Trubisky likely had enough room to run it in himself, but opted to flip the ball to Gabriel for a three-yard score.

“You can’t get a beat on what they do. They have good personnel,” said Redskins outside linebacker Ryan Kerrigan.

On the next possession, after Norman had interfered with Gabriel in the end zone, Trubisky found Gabriel on a short one-yard pass to make it 21-0. A few minutes later, that was followed by the 36-yard strike from Trubisky to Gabriel, who tapped his feet just inside the pylon to score. Norman questioned the officiating on that play and others afterward.

“Let us play, man,” Norman said, shaking his head afterward.

Washington, which has given up an average of 402 yards in its first three games and ranks 26th in the NFL in total defense, stiffened in the second half. Norman came up with an interception after Trubisky underthrew a pass to Allen Robinson at the goal line in the third quarter to keep the Redskins’ faint hopes alive. It was too late. After it was over, Norman returned to his stall and was among the last to leave a silent locker room. He remained optimistic that his unit would “catch a break” as it moves on to New York next week, yet there were still so many lingering questions.

“The only thing we can do is just show up, put on our hard hats and go to work,” Norman said. “That’s all we have, and that’s all we can do.”

authors: Roman Stubbs Is A Sports Reporter For The Washington Post.
